review_title: A terrible place to get experience.
pros: Good place if you need to learn to fend for yourself and develop thick skin.

Training was also very much a "one and done" experience with the demonstration and too many questions from my end could lead to aggressive criticism. The pay was also poor, in fact my supervisor made special arrangements for me so that I was salaried for what was normally an hourly position. Management ignoring employee issues that in the end affect patients services.

Employees trying to do too much with few resources and lack of support.

pros: Management is big on work/life balance (at least in my division). There is a lot of flexibility when it comes to taking time off and working remotely. This is awesome if you have school age children or elderly parents.

review_title: OK but heavily complacent and a mildly arrogant research culture
pros:
World class facility
High profile research mission
Good benefits package
Strong academic links
Strong pediatric sub and ultra-specialties
Good CEO and COO
Excellent preclinical research infrastructure

Intramural funding and support strong

pros: Mission is wonderful; innovative research at best children's hospital
cons:
BCH is a caring and innovative Children's Hospital for its patients. However, for its staff, it is a dumpster fire. Clinicians/PIs run this place with unruly power (they bring in the big $$ so can treat administrators and staff like garbage). Whether a PI likes you can make or break your career here. Management lacks transparency and makes unilateral decisions without discussing with the team, making it abundantly clear that they don't care about employee satisfaction or work culture. The people who actually do the work lack support, are disrespected and are put in the line of fire on a daily basis. BCH is an impossible place to grow your career. 

Benefits are sub-par (1% 401K match, expensive health insurance, time off bucketed with sick days and holidays means everyone comes to work SICK at a HOSPITAL).

pros: employee benefits, excellent patient care
cons: it is an physician, hr, and management ego driven environment that runs the place instead of common sense.

review_title: Excellent research environment but low compensation
pros:
1) You get to work with some of the most talented scientists in the country
2) Being affiliated with Harvard Medical School allows for good research exposure (i.e., ability to work on high impact projects, ability to ascertain funding and materials, and access to career fairs from employers only looking to hire from the HMS community)

cons:
1) Salary should be reflective of the fact that we are living in Boston and being affiliated with Harvard.
2) Hypercompetitve research environment (this could be a good or bad thing depending on your viewpoint). 
3) Colleagues within the same institution may steal your projects/ideas .... keep a TIGHT lip.

review_title: Overall, a great place to work.
pros:
There is pride in working for an organization that does such wonderful things for children and their families.   
There is a clear and noble mission directing the work  that's done here.
They have very fair compensation and good benefits.
Very competent senior leadership has  left Children's in a good financial position compared to other area hospitals.
cons:
It's in a tough commuter location, not very easy for most poeple to get too.
There is the perception that some managers are in their roles because they are "connected" with the right people and therefore are not held to the appropriate level of accountiablity.

review_title: Did not have courtesy to get back to me regarding stays after 4 interviews
pros: The benefits package is one of the best around compared to other area hospitals.  Staff seem to be knowledgeable of their profession.
cons: With Children's Hospital being such a large organization it is easy to be considered as a number and not person.

pros: The hiring process was straightforward and moved quickly. For the most part, everyone I was in contact with was very nice.

I was offered a position, filled out the proper paperwork, was cleared by Occupational Health, picked up my badge, and then was notified that there was no money to fund the position. I was one of two people hired. I acted professionally and respectfully, and was disappointed that I did not get a reply from my would be manager after reaching out. HR did apologize on behalf of the department, but I feel that it was unprofessional to not receive a response directly.

review_title: I love this institution because of what they stand for when it comes to caring for the patients.
job_title: Reception Representative III in Boston, MA
pros: It is a great place to work, and it can teach one to humble themselves, by what you encounter day in and day out.
cons: Management lacks the skill of interpersonal communication, and does not defend their employees, meaning they will be quick to judge before exploring all areas of truth.  Now this is not in every department, and there are some great managers in this facility, however the handful that are not that good can leave a bad taste in ones mouth.

review_title: Could be amazing but a let down
pros:
At Waltham CBAT: 
Working with kids and seeing how resilient they are.
Good coworkers (for the most part) 
Good earned time
cons:
At Waltham CBAT: 
Management is a struggle. Unit director has never been a counselor on a floor before 
Counselors are treated as less than by the nurses an management 
Counselors concerns about patients do not seem to have as much of an impact as they should
Counselors, the people who spend the most time with the kids, are not allowed in treatment meetings. 
Over-utilization of benign neglect techniques.

pros: Generally an up-beat place to work with a very diverse and accepting environment.  Working to help children and their families is very rewarding.
cons: HR is horrible.  Advancement can be elusive and with no explanation from management.  People who want to advance their careers should be allowed to work hard and do just that.  If its not happening they should be given a reason so they can improve themselves.  Also, very cheap company.  Annual salary increases have been locked at a sad 2 percent for all staff which doesn't even cover the increase in the cost of living.  Oh an no bonuses allowed.

pros: The mission and the people it attracts is first rate.
cons:
Leadership at The Trust is very poor, in particular the President lacks vision. She has created a culture where silos are common which means that people are at odds with goals. Dysfunction abounds which Leadership is aware of. 

Periodically they try to placate staff with ludicrous so called morale boosters.  A great example is  the "treat train"  where one to two times a year the Executive Team will come around the office with something sweet like cookies or cake. Staff would prefer that the Executive Team instead address large, systemic problems.

Benefits are poor, ironically maternity leave is the bare minimum. Also ironically there is no dedicated sick time so employees regularly come in to work sick to preserve  their PTO.

review_title: It was the best job I have had thus far.
pros: A teaching hospital is a great place to learn and teach others.  A very positive experience.  The benefits are fantastic.  Here you can make a difference in many children's lives.  The surrounding town is fun and beautiful to be in.  Children's will teach you necessary skills to move up for free.
cons: It can be far to drive and traffic troublesome.  If you are not use to strangers, this is not the place for you.

pros: Children's Hospital is world renowned and as such working for the hospital feels good. Being part of an organization that provides amazing care and cutting edge treatment is inspirational. The hospital provides an array of services for their patients and families from medical care to social work to providing resources or links to resources. There is constant learning and encouragement of ongoing learning.
cons:
It is average when it comes to employee benefits. The earned time off bank is used for sick time, vacation time and holidays. It is not beneficial to employees. Health care was slightly more expensive than my spouse's plans. There are no exceptional benefits as one would think working for such a recognized institution. Raises are minimal although the annual review process is extensive. 
There could be more flexibility for some staff to work remotely.

pros: Incredible autonomy, respect from physicians, challenging learning environment, great charge nurses and resource staff,  amazing opportunity to help patients with rare congenital heart conditions and their families.  Constant exposure to research, up and coming technology, and advancement in healthcare
cons: huge turnover a few years ago, popularity contest for the best assignment,  lateral violence between young nurses without consequence, management not fostering a culture of support, at times unsafe assignments

pros: Helping the Children.  It's job until you find another one.  Working with some of the staff and doctors.
cons: It depends on the department.  My was awful, micromanagement, the managers had no respect for the staff.  VERY VERY high turnover.   The pay was too low, not livable in the Boston and surrounding areas. I  even saw some of the staff fired / not hired back if they were out on Medical leave even though they wanted to come back to work. Managers could bring in someone else at a cheaper pay rate.  Some of the parents.  Half the departments are "Foundations", which rents the Children's name.

pros: This hospital is the best of the best, so it's easy to have a lot of pride in the organization.  Everyone genuinely wants to provide the best care possible to the patients.  Hospital leadership is wonderful and are great professionals to look up to.
cons: Many departments are silos and it's difficult to work collaboratively.  The nature of the work is so wrapped up in necessary compliance and regulations that it's created a culture that makes attempted collaboration hard.  There are also a lot of egos to deal with.  Benefits are not what you would hope for from a world class medical institution.

review_title: Experience, Lots of Work, Tough Culture
pros:
The brand is a resume builder
The mission is wonderful and the hospital really helps children
Some coworkers are very talented and dedicated
You will learn skills that will serve you in the future
Some of the senior leaders are among the best I've seen

You will most likely learn by fire under really difficult stressful circumstances

pros: Incredible mission, 75% of people were really great people to work with, good benefits,

review_title: Great place to work with wonderful colleagues and benefits
pros: Children's is a wonderful company to work for. There is a great focus on employee development and overall collegiate atmosphere. The health benefits offered to employees are reasonably priced and a wide variety of services are also electable.
cons: Annual reviews are frustrating because department heads have to end with a balanced team rating. The system is set up such that one cannot get an exceedingly excellent numerical review without another member of the team getting a bad review.

review_title: The disfunction starts at the Sr. Leadership level- their HR department is from the Jurassic ages
job_title: Very Close to the Truth in Boston, MA

review_title: Great short term job for experience

review_title: Poor Senior Management takes away from the positive mission and purpose of Children's Hospital Boston.
job_title: Ambulatory Services Representative II in Boston, MA
pros:
If you work with individuals who are well-aligned with the fundamental missions of the hospital, you will find a sense of purpose no matter your role.  Seeing children passing through the halls will easily bring a smile to your face and act as a constant reminder that what you do has a positive impact on the community.  

Working for a hospital, the health benefits are unparalleled.  The pay is good if you transitioned from the retail industry, as I did, even though it is on the lower side of the scale.  The time off is rather generous as well, offering 30 days of vacation/holiday/sick pay.
cons:
If you are looking to move up quickly, this is certainly not the place to do so.  Managers value longevity above individual competence and an eagerness to learn and grow.  I worked in an entry-level customer service role, and despite having management experience with Nordstrom (a leader in customer service), as well as a BA in business and retail management, they wanted to keep me in the same low-paying position for 1 1/2 to 2 years.  I found it rather appalling as I demonstrated that I was over qualified for the job and expressed a strong desire to grow within the hospital.

The managers also do not understand that human capital is the most valuable asset to any company.  They do not offer constructive and/or regular performance feedback.  They do not want to invest time and energy into coaching and developing existing employees for peak performance.  Instead, they are quick to criticize and demoralize.  This is not simply from my own experience, but two others in the hospital.  The level of professionalism is very questionable among senior management (in terms of how they treat employees), and I suspect it is because their whole careers have been in health care and no other areas of business.

pros:

I worked along side of the best physicians in their field.  While there were definitely some egos, it was still an experience of a lifetime for me.
cons: Lots of bureaucracy.  Took a long time to get things done.

job_title: Ambulatory Service Representative II in Boston, MA
pros:
-For the training program, they recruit young recent college gradates. Most of the people will be around your age and you do get to know some people in your group.
-For a period of 3 months you float around to different departments either in the front or back end of clinics. Its a great way to get to know the hospital and all the different clinics it has.
-There is a lot of epic training, almost too much. We were taught to make a brand new patient about twenty times, I don't think anyone during the duration of the program even made a new patient in the clinic setting.
-Good benefits. After your 90 day probation period you have 30 paid days off for a year, 50% off public transportation, you can use the LMA shuttle, and theres $5,000 tuition reimbursement per semester.
-Now I'm done with the training program and I never have to see the supervisor anymore. I like the department I'm in so far now.
cons:
-The main downside to the training program was my boss. She micromanages, you don't even see her except for the weekly meetings which were a waste of time.  
-You don't really to get to choose to where you float to, I think there should be more of a say to where we would like to be. If the training program is to promote longevity this should be a major concern. It doesn't make sense to put someone in a phone call center if they would never apply, while there are people who do like the back end work. 
-The training was way too long. I felt like I was in high school again. Anyone over the age of 25 is too old or this program almost, I mean taking a 4 hour class while we learn about empathy and how to talk to patients and their families? Really? Anyone who has had a job dealing with people should already have this skill. Its a total waste of money from the hospital, while the money could go to something more useful.
-At the end of the training program you are able to apply to job openings, the supervisor has to approve it first. I never understood this, if you feel you're ready to apply why can't you apply? You're not in the training program forever.
-I would not do the training program if I had a to do over. I would do my own research and just apply on my own.
